div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN BOOM.
div.p: ( Concluded.)

All the same, it is important to ascertain he causes which have created that discontent d party and the grievances of which it com blains. The causes are essentially human,and n some degree natural. The motto on Mustapha Kamel's newspaper, The Egyptian Standard, hose first number was issued in March last, is "Egypt for the Egyptians," This is a catching entiment, and indicates that the aim of the arty is to get rid of British guidance. It is be ery of the petulant boy, against the disapline of his tutor, and in that respect is very buman, but not necessarily reasonable. It ignore the fact that British guidance has delivered Egypt from a system of autocratic rule which ruined Egypt for the Egyptians, has developed to an andreamed of extent. the natural resouroes of the country, has substituted progress for stagnation and civilising, influences for barbaric ways. These results are not denied by the National ist party, but its contention today is that it is now able to do without its mentor and govern alone. That this pretension is unfounded even impartial Egyptians acknowledge. After an absence from the country of ten years, I was rejoiged to observe the marked progress which the spread of education is making. I saw a type of young Egyptians at the Government offices, at the railway stations and steam-boat agencies, well-mannered, educated, intelligent, which scarcely existed a decade ago; and when I made this remark to the best informed education ist in the country, he replied, "You forget that every year, we have been turning out from our schools six to seven hundred such young men, and in ten years that counts." I noticed that at important Mediries where ten years ago British functionaries were in charge, I found their place occupied, and most creditably ocupied, by Peyptians. Progress is evident. Education and inocula tion from hodest surroundings and good example are showing their fruits on the Payptinn character. But it requires more than decade for a nation which only began its education when British guidance made it possible to acquire the qualities which reoder it capable of self-government. The essential is that the growth in the acquisition of these qualities should be gradual and continuous, and I had pleasure in being satisfied that such is the case in Egypt. The pretension, however, implied in the motto of the Nationalist part-"Egypt for Egyptina--is prematare, and must at present be declared unreasonable Of actual grievances I could hear of none which justify the hostile attitude of the Nationalist party to the present rígime. In the second number of Mustapha Kamel's paper, "The Egyptian Standard," there is a lengthy denunciation of what is called Lord Cromer's policy, qualified antiEgyptian It asserts, in the first place, that "not all Egyptians have profited by the apparent state of prosperity, and that misery is common among the poorer classes"; in the second place, that "the Egyptians did not revolt in 1889 in order to pre several millions sterling more in the excbequer, but to obtain a constitution, just laws, and a national, bonest, and respected goremament." It is ridiculous to talk of misery among the poorer classes when wages are at least 40 per cent higher than ever before. Of the revolt of 1882 the least said, the better. It was its failure which brought to Egypt just laws and an honest government. The article goes on to say that the same policy strack down the late Menabawi Pashs, and it did not hesitate in ponishing the poor fellaheen in the horrible Denshawi case, simply because they had defended their property and their wives." This latter is a ourious travesty of panishments inflicted for brutally Assaulting British officers. As to Menshawi Pasha, rich and influential, he was justly arrested and punished by a court of law for mistreating a poor subordinata The article proceeds to criticise the pre motion of a judge, against whom the only fault alleged is that how members of the court which tried the Denshawions, the dismissal of two other judges" because they were patriots." The fact is, serious gries anoes there are one. The solo grievance of the discontented party is that they are not in power but it would be unwise to put men in power who cry for parliamentary government before the country is educated up to it to who declare themselves hostile to a regime which has made the country prosperous, in which administers even-handed justice to small and great. Discontent springing from intentional ambitions requires only a firm and jus hand to deal with it. With the freedom, pe haps too. grost, allowed to the Preseth noise of the discontented is out of all proportion to their importance, but, however irritation the noise may be, it need ones no serion alarm. Our duty is steadfastly to pursue firm, jast, and strong policy, having only i view the true interests, moral and material of Egypt. Such, undoubtedly, was the policy of Lord Cromer, and it was the secret of his great success It would have been agreeable to me tu describe in detail the impressions produced gpon my mind by my visit to Khartoum. Simply marvellous are the results which in for short years have been achieved in the Anglo-Egyptian territory of the Sudan, in area equal to a fourth of Europe) by the able and energetic administration of Sir Reginak Wingate and his coadjutors. Immenso also the future prospects of that last region, over which, after years of darkness, the light of civilisation is now drawing. Bat my space will not admit of my entering upon such a largo, and interesting field. It is besides unconnected with the subject of this article The Egyptian Boom," a remarkable wave of prosperity which, although it may have temporarily intoxicated some, has largely been fitted, and will continue to benefit, and country in whose destiny England is greatly interested ("Blackwood's Magazine.")

div.p: The efforts pat forth by Governor of Dovgola Province to get rid of the locusts there have proved successful. Nothing more is heard about them. It is hoped that they have disappeared for good and all.

div.head: Eeneh Barrage.
div.p: The ironwork contract placed by the Government with Messrs Ramsomes and Rapier of London and Ipswich has made a good start: A large quantity of the material is on the ground and is being erected under the direction Mr. G. S. Perry.

div.head: Important Property Sale,
div.p: The building known as the "Maison Zaher," opposite Shepleard's Hotel, has been sold to Mr. Nessim Afifi for £80,000. The building was bought a few months ago by Ahmed Bey Farghal fór £75,000, who has thus cleared profit of £5,000.

div.head: Cattle Plague.
div.p: During the week ending the 1st July, 41% fatal cases of cattle plague were registered throughout Egypt, of which 25 occurred in the province of Sharkieh, 4 in that of Kalioubieb, 16 at Ghizeh, 9 in the Fayoum, 63 in the district of Beni-Soner, 124 in that of Minieh and 174 in Assiout district

div.head: Births and Deaths.
div.p: From the 2nd to the 8th instant inclusive, 523 births including 12 of European parentage, and 311 deaths including 19 Europeans were registered in Cairo. The deaths comprised 161 adults of whom 7 were Europeans and 150 children under 5 years of age, of whom 12 were Europeans. Of the deaths 5 were due to dyphtheria, 14 to typhus, 5 to typhoid, 66 to measles, 1 to smallpox and 1 to erysipelis.

div.head: Bourse and Banking Co.
div.p: An extraordinary meeting of the Alexandria Stock and Shareholders Association will be held on Monday next to consider the adoption of some measures for the regulation of the transactions of the Bourse and Banking Company of Egypt, Limited. The meeting will also elect three new members to replace Messrs. J. Arditi, P. Augustino, and. D. Klat, who have resigned

div.head: The San Stefano Season,
div.p: In a few days the additions to the San Stefano Hotel will be completely finished and then the hotel will have 175 rooms at the disposition of visitors. This is an addition of sixty rooms since last year. The Club has been transferred to the first floor, a large verandah and a special bar and restaurant have been added. A new bakery has been finished and is now working. All the bread for the establishment is now supplied from there. The total number of complete suites with bathrooms and toilet cabinets is now twenty. Nive musicians and singers are arriving from Italy on Monday next, and the first concert will be given on Wednesday next in the great Salle des Fêtes of the Casino. They will perform .every Thursday and Sunday afternoon on the grand terrace and will be accompanied by the Bracale Orchestra.

div.head: Egyptian Motor Traotion Co.
div.p: The extraordinary and ordinary general meeting of the Egyptian Motor Traction Company, which is to be held on the 16th inst, will come to a final decision on the subject of renewing their stock of buses as their old motor buses were not found suitable for the road. The extraordinary meeting will be convened to decide to call in the capital so as to make the shares fully paid up. Up to now £2 of the £4 have only been paid. Probably both these decisions will be voted and then the company will start on a new lease of life. The trouble with the motor buses at Alexandria is the continued need of repairs. The company hopes to enter into a new contract with the firm supplying the motor buses on the subject of the repairs, so that for a round suin annually all the repairs will be undertaken, which will guarantee the success of the concern.

div.head: LIQUIDATION PROPOSALS
div.p: An extraordinary general meeting of the North Egypt Land Company, Limited, will be held at the registered office of the Company, 14. Great Winchester Street, London, on the 23rd inst. for the purpose of considering, and, if thought fit, passing a resolution to the effect that the Company be wound up. voluntarily, and that Mr. John Baker, of the firm of Messrs. Baker, Sutton and Co., chartered accountants, be appointed liquidator for the purpose of winding up. The formal notice of the meeting will be found on page 4 of to-day's issue.

The tug "Hercule," which has been built for the Suez Canal Company by Messrs. J.P. Rennoldson and Sons, of South Shields, has just taken up her duties in the Canal. It is claimed that she is the most powerful tog afloat, and this may well be 80, seeing that her machinery is of 8,000.i.h.p. She is a twin screw.vessel, 158 ft. long by 32 ft. beam and 17 ft. deep, classed 100 A1 at Lloyd's. Two centrifugal salvage pumps capable of discharging 700 tons per hour, and a fire-pump by Messrs. Merryweather, with a capacity of 650 gallons per minute, are installed on board. The deck machinery consists of a steam windlass, tiro steam capstans, and two steam-driven reels for working the towing hawsers. There is a saloon in the fore part, and electric light, including a powerful Suez type projector, are fitted. The "Hercule" is an improved sister ship of the WTitan," built by the same firm for the Suez Canal Company about eight years ago.

Lord and Lady Cromer have bought one of the large empty houses in Wimpole St. which they are having redone up as their permanent town residence. Lord Errington, Lord Cromer's heir, will reside there. Lord Cromer, has been taking a rest cure and is reported to be now in much better health. He returned to London on Thursday 4th inst.

div.head:
OBITUARY.
MR. GIUSEPPE CAMPOS.
div.p: We regret to announce the death of Mr. Giuseppe Campos, which took place yesterday evening at 7 o'clock at his residence 17 Rosetta-street, Alexandria. Mr. Campos was in his usual health up to last Saturday when an abscess gathered in his throat to which he succumbed. Mr. Campos arrived in Egypt in 1854 and was among the first Alexandrian cotton operators. He was a courteous and genial old gentleman and his death will be regretted by a large number of friends among all classes of society in Egypt. He was over seventy years of age. As a mark of sympathy the Alexandria Bourse instead of opening this morning at 10.30 o'clock opened half an hour Inter. We beg to tender one sincere sympathy with his widow and his two sons, Mr. Alfred and Mr. Benvenuto Campos, in their bereavement. The funeral will leave the residence of the deceased, 17 Rosetta Street; at 6 o'clock this afternoon, Friends "and acquaintances, who have not yet received notice, are requested to accept this as an invitation to attend.
A Cairo correspondent writes -

Complaints against the Cairo City Police are very frequent and although in many cases reasonable grounds of complaint are produced, yet complainants are frequently ignorant of the real facts of the case. For example: it is a well known fact, or should be, that the Cairo City Police are very much understaffed ; not on paper, but for practical purposes, and great deal, in fact by far the larger part of the capital 18 patrolled by ghaflirs owing to the shortness of the uniformed staff. The explanation is not very difficult to find. A very large number of uniformed staff are on duty at banks and other public institutions. In fact the public would be surprised to know the actual percentage of the public forces soconded in this manner. Consequently the police are subjected to all sorts of criticism from individuals who do not know the real facts.

div.head:
MARIOUT DEVELOPMENT
THR KHEDIVE'S RAILWAY.
div.p: The Khedive's line, which is advancing gradually westwards from its . terminus at Wardian to Marsa Matrouh, has been of great benefit in developing the Mariout district. Last week the big condensing station, which his Highness has been constructing at Hammam was completed. It cost £3,500 and will purify the water for the engines on his line. Although the water at Hammam is excellent for drinking purposes, it contains lime which has bad effects on the boilers and makes a condensing apparatus a necessity. The machinery, which is of Austrian make, is of the latest pattern. Another similar installation of condensing plant is to be set up at Dabbah.

One of the important factors in the development of the Mariout district is the exploitation of gypsum, which is such a valuable commodity for building. The Khedive has built a new siding on his line at Cherbanyet for transporting the gypsum, as his Highness has about 400 feddans of gypsum there."
THE MARKETS.

The market at Sidi Abdul Rahman, which was instituted by the Khediye last year, is growing in importance and is attended by an increasing number of people from the neighbourhood. There are four markets in Mariout, all of which were established by the Khedive, Hamman, Mondays, Beheig, Tuesdays, Amrieh Wednesdays, and Sidi Abdul Rahman, Saturdays.
THE MARIOUT SURVEY.

The survey of the Mariout district is proceeding satisfactorily and Mr. Montagu and Mr. Murray, who have been entrusted with this work, have reached Amrich, where their camp is now pitched. The operations of the survey of the north western district of Egypt is to extend up to the frontier of Tripoli at Salloum, and is to include the Oasis of Siwa on the South. It is expected that the work will take at least three years. There is at present no map of the country to the West of Alexandria. In fact even the frontier line is not determined, a fact of which the Turks took advantage of in occupying the important position of Sollom with its excellent harbour The survey will also be of considerable importance in the delimitation of the cultivated land which is increasing every year in area in this district
THE TELEGRAPH.
The telegraph line from Alexandria to Marsa Matronh was completed on the 28th ulta. Communication from Mersa Matrouh to the extreme westerly coast guard post at Sidi Berand is conducted by telephone
THE POLICE

The general state of public security in the Marion district is very good. Last month there were only seven police cases, which consisted of petty quarrels among the Bedonin inhabitants. The lawlessness prevailing there has greatly lessened during the past few years since the district was transferred to the control of the Alexandria Police from the Behera Moudirieb.

The police will probably make a new station at El Anned shortly. There are now three stations, at Antrieb, 14 men and 8 horses. Beheig, I men and 6 horses, and Hamman, where the Camel Corps is stationed consisting of 10 men and 8 camels. These stations are under the inspection of Sagh. Kelham, and under the command of Yousbashi Mahmoud Sidky, the Mamour.

div.head: PLAGUE AT ALEXANDRIA
div.p: Another case of plague occurred at Alexandria at the Hotel de la Poste yesterday, the victim being Mme. Agolhon, widow of the proprietor, who died from the plague the day before yesterday. Mme. Agulhon was taken to the Greek hospital yesterday afternoon and lies there in a precarious condition.
The hotel has been denounced by the sanitary authorities as unclean and infected by rats and mice, and the usual steps are being taken for disinfection and deratisation.

The origin of the outbreak at this hotel is believed to be from a young Austrian man, and clerk of the Austrian Lloyd Steam ! ship Company Ltd., and by the name of Isetich, 25 years of age. Suffering greatly from his eyes, Izetich came from Suez to Alexandria for treatment and took a room at the Hotel de la Poste. His was the first case to be detected and, terminating fatally, he was buried yesterday morning.
The official bulletin issued to-day also reports 1 death out of hospital at Beba, 2 recoveries at Beni Mazar, 1 death in hospital at Damanhour, all of whom nativer.

div.head:
THE EGYPTIAN PORTS.
STATISTICS OF NAVIGATION
div.p: A most interesting and useful compilation of statistics of the movement of shipping in the ports of Egypt has been issued by the Statistical Department of the Ministry of Finance. The most interesting statistics given will be published in our columns in and future issue. Meanwhile we publish the introductory remarks of the Director of the Department, which, we trust, will receive the fullest consideration from all shipping agoricios hero. The Director writes:

The object of this Department in undertaking the organization of this enquiry was to collect and publish fall information on both the maritime commerce and navigation, and not only the movement of shipping which the pregent volume deals with. It is true that the quarterly returns issued during the year 1906, which are summarized in this volume, contained some data concerning passengers. But figures relating to landing passengers only, have a real value, for, this information is sapphed by the Quarantine Board whose officials Bre in a position to collectit with due accuracy. As to passengers embarked, the data furnished to this Department are very far from being correct The Bureau of Passports, which ought to be in a position to collect this information, has, on the one hand, a rather defective method of registering and, on the other hand, travellers are not obliged by the local regulations to make any statement at their departure and no passport is strictly required. Therefore, no information on passengers is given in this volume.

From the beginning of 1906 this Department established a method of direct information by franchised postcards, which must be sent to this Department by the shipping agents at every departure and arrival of boats. In these nostoards the agents have to put down the tonnage of goods and the number of passengers embarked and landed. Very many among the most important shipping agencies established in the four principal ports of Egypt have agreed to send and are still forwarding the required statements. I am very grateful to these agents for their kind support, and bog to request that they will persevere in their cooperation in the future. Unfortunately many other agencies have not answered to the demand of this Department. I take the liberty of assuring them their reluctance pre indices both the interests of the companies they represent and the interests of the countries to which these companies belong and for whose benefit this enquiry is chiefly intended.

The Government is, in this behalf, mainly inspired by its duty of throwing light on every field of the country's activity, in order to place at the disposal of those who are interested the means of increasing their own well-being. Nevertheless, this Department, trusting in the support given by the important agencies, persists in its first purpose, and hopes to soon be able to obtain the consent and co-operation of the hesitating minority of agents..

With a view of facilitating the desired achievement, this Department has elaborated a new scheme which will be applied from January next, replacing the postcards system, This new plan is much simpler than the former. Thus, I hope that, on account of the trivial work which it will cause to the agents and the securities it offers to them, this Bureau may may be able to publish next year complete information on the maritime commerce and passenger traffic with foreign countries, attaining this the end to which the constant efforts of this Department are directed.

div.head:
GOVERNOR OF LEBANON.
DEMONSTRATION AT BEYROUT
div.p: In view of the appointment of Youssef Bey Cussa Franco as Governor of the Lebanon, the following communication from our Beyrout correspondent, despatched on the 3rd inst, is of especial interest

It having been ascertained that active steps were being taken at Constantinople and in high quarters, by the chiefs of the party that had been in the ascendency during the regime of Naoum Pasha for the renomination of the latter, or in default of that of one of his family such as Youssef Bey Franco, his brother-inlaw, a large crowd of the Opposition party, numbering over two thousand Lebanese Christians and Druses, came down to Beyrout and made an important demonstration at the Seraglio at different Consulates General. An eye witness says that at the Seraglio the representative heads of the crowd clamoured for justice and appealed to the Vali to solicit His Majesty to see that a just and upright Governor should at last be sent to Lebanon and save the further oppression of the desperate population. His Excellency haying calmed them with kind promises loud cheers and acclamations burst from the crowd with loud clapping of hands

div.head: MEDITERRANEAN FLEET'S VISIT.
div.p: A meeting of the entertainment committee of the British residents of Alexandria was held at the Union Club on Friday afternoon last.

Present: . Admiral Sir R. Massie Blomfield, R.N. (chairman), Mr. R. J. Moss (vice-chairman and hon. treasurer), Messrs. C. A. Greig, (acting consul), K. P. Birley, H. B. Carver, W. P. Chataway, H. P. A lam, A. S. Preston, and W. F. Sarjeant. Messrs. E. W. P. Foster, C.M.G., H. E. Barker, and R. G. Grandy were unable to attend.
The accounts, were submitted and passed. These are now open to the inspection of subscribers upon application to Mr. Alfred Fabri, at the offices of Messrs. R. J. Moss and Co.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: The Sirdar and Lady Wingate are staying at Dunbar.
Fakhry Pasha has left Constantinople for the Island of Thathos, where he will pass a week before returning to Egypt.
Borton Boy is at present on a tour of inspection in the provinces.
Captain Lyons, Director of the Survey Department, has returned to Cairo from leave in Europe.
Miralai J. Schalch Bey, Commandant of the Suez Canal Police, has been granted two and a half month's leave of absence from the 17th inst.
M E. Marton. Director of Stores, Ministry of the Interior, will go on leave on the 3rd prox. for three and a half months.
Dr. Keatinge has left for Europe on his annual holiday, which he will spend in Austria: He will return to Cairo early in August.

Abdel Karim Bey Fehmy, Chef du Bureau, Ministry of the Interior, has retired and has been placed on the pension. In accepting his resignation the Minister expressed his appreciation of the excellent services he has rendered.
Ahmed Bey Kamiha has been appointed sub-director of the Khedivial Law School.

The marriage was solemnised at All Souls: Langham Place, W. on Tuesday in last week, of Mr. Errol Kerr, of Alexandria, son of the late Mr. Angus Kerr, of Edinburgh, and Miss Daisy Lereaux, daughter of the late Mr. I. Leveaux and Mrs. Winter, 6, Welbeck St. W
Captain Kelly. *3rd Ausgars, and Captain D. McEeod, Gordon Highlanders, have been seconded in their respective regiments for service with the Egyptian Army.

Second Lieutenant J. A. Brooke, 2nd Battalion Northumberland Posilióra, Tidworth Camp, has been transferred to the 6th Inniskilling Dragoons at Cairo. He got his commission in the "Fighting Fifth" in May 1905.
Mrs. W. F. and Master Sarjeant are leaving for England next week by the S.S. "Mandalay."

div.head: The Lost corps
div.p: The "Sudan Times" reports that a court of enquiry was held about the middle of June to enquire into the Bir Natron affair. Kaim. Jackson Boy, who presided at the Court, has just returned from Debba. The report of the court has not yet been made known, but we understand that no new frots have been elicited in addition to what is already known about this unfortunate affair.

The enquiry does not imply any unfavourable reflection upon the military authorities concerned, but is in the regular course of events. It is the rule that after the occurrence of an event of this sort an enquiry is made in order to ascertain and put on record all the particulars pertaining to it.

We learn that the search parties which went out to look for the missing men met with many hardships. The heat was so intense that even the Bedouins who accompanied the party sufig red from it. Their supply of water was used up so fast that they could not extend their search as they had first intended.
The Camel Corps post at Bir Natrun has now been withdrawn, at least until next October. In the meanwhile it is stationed at Dongola.

div.head:
EGYPT 100 YEARS AGO.
THE BATTLE OF ROSETTA.
div.p: A hundred years ago the most serious defeat that England ever met with in Egypt happened and by a curious coincidence the Scotch general, who led the troops and perished in the disaster, bore the same name and belonged to the same family as the general who fell a few years ago in the most serious disaster that befell us in the Boer war, The following is the first account of the calamity, which reached England and appeared in the "Times" of June 12th, 1807 :

The "Pompée," Sir Sidney Smith, whose Approval from the Mediterranean we announced yesterday, has brought intelligence of a very unpleasant nature. That part of our army, which was detached from Alexandria against Rosetta, has been defeated with great loss. Our readers will recollect, that in our anticipation of the Hamburg Mailon Wednesday, we alluded to this melancholy ovent. The private information which we then were in possession of, would have justified as in announcing it in a much stronger manner.

That we did not was owing to the peculiar delicacy of the circumstance, as well as the difficulty of the situation in which we were placed. Thó bouro from which we derived our intelligence,' has in no one instance ever misled us, and its communications are entitled to implicit confidence and respect; but we shrunk from being the first to announce great public calamity. We, therefore, restricted, our communication to hinting at the disaster, and stating the scene of the misfortune, confident that the melancholy corroboration of our intelligence could not be long delayed.

The particulars of this unfortunate affair, as well as we have been able to collect them, are these. It is known, though the fasot is not stated in General Fraser's dispatch, that immediately after the surrender of Alexandria, and respectable force was detached by him against Rosetta, the command of which was confided to Major General Wanchope. They advanced against it under the impression that they should moot with no resistance. No forco appeared for the purpose of obstructing their march. The head of the column had, however, scarcely entered the town, when it was assailed by a destructive fire from a vast number of Turks and Albanians, who were posted in the houses and different buildings. The contest was unequal, and our troops were under the necessity of retreating. They accordingly evacuated the town, and took the best position they could, under the circumstances ; but kaving, as we are informed, been joined by some reinforcements from Alexandria, they again advanced, and gave battle to an enemy infinitely superior to them in numbers. The result was such as we set out with stating; they were defeated, with very great loss indeed. In the first affair, the extent of our loss was about 150 killed and wounded. In the second, it was upwards of s thousand. We have not been able to ascertain whether any prisoners were made; bot the total loss was probably not much under 1200 mer, or half perhaps of the force which was engaged. The remains of this gallant little band made good their retreat to Alexandria where they remain. The Commander of the expedition, Major General Wauchope, fell. Brigadier General Meade, the next in command, was wounded, but, we are happy to bear, not badly. Several other officers were also slightly wounded, who were fast recovering - when the dispatches were sent off.
Saturday, June 18

We have little to add to the particulars of the recent disaster in Egypt which we gave yesterday. A Packet from Malte arrived at Falmouth on Tuesday, but it has not brought 30 late intelligence as the "Pompée," which sailed some days after. The official account of the second action, fought, as it is said, on the 19th of April, bas not we understand, been yet received; that of the first has, and will probably appear in the Gazette of this evening.

We are not yet sufficiently in porsession of the circumstances of this unexpected event to be able to pronounce an impartial opinion upon it. The first action, as we have before stated, took place in the town of Rosetta, into which, it is said the division under General Wauchope incautiously entered. It is possible that the little resistance made at Alexandria, and the persuasion that the population of the country were friendly, might have lulled that officer into a confidence, which has been attended with fatal results. This is some excuse for him; and the manner and gallantry of his fall is sufficient atonement for his indiscretion, if any there has been. But to such indulgence we cannot admit the second attempt is in the least entitled. Nothing but the certainty of a décisive victory, or to avoid the horrors of impending famine, should have induced the officer, who had the chief command, to risk a second action.

div.head:
CONGO FREE STATE
ANNEXATION DECIDED UPON.

div.p: The Government has resolved to annex the congo Free State. A bill will be introduced for this purpose. (Reuter)

div.head:
THE HAGUE CONFERENCE.
QUESTION OF MINES

div.p: Germany has submitted an amendment per pitting the laying of automatic contact mines all water where operations are proceeding are expected to take place. (Reuter)

div.head:

DANGER OP HEROIC REMEDIES.

div.head:
KING PARDONS LYNCH.
THE BOER TRAITOR

div.p: The King has granted a free pardon to lynch, who was convicted for high trenon in 123 for fighting on the side of the Boers. Hes liberatel in 1904 (Reuter)

div.head: THE INSIGNIA BURGLARY. JEWELLERY ALSO MISSING

div.p: Family jewellery valued at £1,500 belonging to Sir Arthur Vicars is missing from the Same safe in which the Royal Insignia of the Order of St. Patrick was kept. The use is tact but was found open (Reuter)
News of Kaid Maclean say that the K mass tribe are negotiating with the Sultan for its pardon and that of Baisoli. (Havas)

The Crown Hotel at Boksburg, near here, was blown up by dynamite last night. The occupants escaped with little hurt. An attempt was also made to blow up the water-main of three mines with dynamite but was practically abortive. (Reuter)
Mr. Alfred Billson took ill in the lobby of the House of Commons and died The House aljoumed, Sir H. Campbell Bannerman Eriefly paying him a tribute. (Reuter)
The Khedive has left Constantinople for Vienna (Havas)
The positions of Japan and America are widely discussed. Diplomats hope for an understanding between the two countries. (H.)

div.head: The Money Market
div.p: There has been quite a glut of floating credit in Lombard Street this week, which continues in spite of heavy repayments to the Bank. This plethora of money is likely to be further increased to-day by the dividend payments. Yesterday no more than 1 to 2 per cent could be obtained for short loans, while three months bills were easy at 8 percent.

Egypt has not taken any more gold this week, but in the best-informed circles it is now anticipated that when the present crisis is passed, further imports will be made in order to assist in restoring things to a normal position. The prospects of an excellent cotton crop, and the high prices now obtained for yarn make it certain that a considerable quantity of gold will be required for Egypt in the autumn. Besides, inasmuch as we shall probably ere long need still higher quotations for Egyptian cotton, in view of the possibility of & short American supply, the amount of gold required next winter will surely be considerable.

On the other hand, there are some who say that since only a small portion of the nine millions taken for Egypt last autumn was returned, it is reasonable to suppose that some, at least, of the balance will be available for use in the moving of this year's crop

The Bank return this week shows a heavy shrinkage in the reserve as the result of the half-yearly currency requirements. The amount of £1.097,000 was received from abroad, but £1,432,000 in coin and £768 00 in notes went into home currency, and the reserve there tore £1,103.000 lower. at £23,681,000, the proportion to liabilities being down 4.39 per cent. to 39.34 per cent. Last year at this date the reserve stood at £24,968,889, and the proportion at 41.23 per cent.
The price of har gold is unchanged on the wook at 77/97.

div.head: Silver
div.p: There has been a revival of purchases for the Indian Bazaars, and the market has been very fim. The quotation for bar silver has improved to 31, 1/16.

div.head: The Stock Markets
div.p: Since our last the big financiers connected with affairs Egyptian have experienced a week of more or less anxiety, as a result of the difficulties created by the suspension of the Cassa di Sconto e di Risparmio. So great is the confidence of the Egyptien investing public in Sir Emest Cassel that as soon as it was known that he and his friends were interesting themselves in the affair, a great deal of the anxiety regarding the ultimate settlement disappeared ; nevertheless, it is obvious that there was much work to be done before this much-to-be desired result was accomplished. The final arrangements were come to yesterday for the voluntary liquidation of the Cassa, and the thanks of the whole backing and financial community in Egypt, as well as those who desire to 100 thou proliant unsatisfactory 1 position liquidated, are due to Sir Ernest Cassel and his colleagues for the masterly way in which they have overcome the present difficulties.

These astute financiers, as we informed you in our cable to day, have placed around quarter of a million, or more, if necessary, at the disposal of the Cassa to enable the Bank to meet its present liabilities, so that the process of winding-up voluntarily can be carried out quietly, and the sold securities liquidated without haste. This is eminently satisfactory, and now that this very serious matter is cleared up, we may hope that we have seen the worst of the crisis. Of course, it must be proven that there will be still more wreckage to be dealt with, but none of it is likely to prove of serious import, and is mainly connected with smaller companies, who have been trading beyond their means. With the prospect of a bumper cotton crop, and increasingly high prices, referred to above, we may look forward to the future with confidence, secure in the knowledge that the unhappy crisis through which we have been passing is but temporary, and has not the potentiality to seriously check the course of Egypt's prosperity. The country is sound in every respect and the lessons of the present difficulties, if taken to heart, will prove wholesome. Genuine investors have had a splendid opportunity, of Requiring some of Egypt's sound securities at well below their intrinsic worth, and the amount of money which has been found for the purpose both here and in Paris runs into very large figures and has been pleasant surprise to those behind the scenes

The Bourse speculating punter must not again be allowed to resume the reckless gambling so much in evidence last winter, and the indiscriminate formation of new companies will also have received a wholesome check.

The announcement that the Cask difficulties had been satisfactorily settled had a good effect upon the stock markets generally yesterday, and the tone became much more cheerful. There was an appreciable amount of investment buying in several departments, and prices were firmer.
Today there is little business passing, but the tone is on the whole favourable.

div.head: Consols
div.p: The market for gilt-edged securities has failed to maintain last week's advance, the downward movement being helped by the report that a new loan for the County of Middlesex was about to be issued. Consols are now quoted at 84 for the account.

div.head: Foreign Bonds.
div.p: The leading international bonds have been quiet for the most part, but quotations have been well maintained. Russians show little change, the Fives being quoted 82] and the Fours 737.
There was some demand for Japanese yesterday, the Fours (1905) improving to 847 and several other stocks

div.head: Home Ralls.
div.p: After the temporary improvement recorded last week, home railway shares have agaia been neglected, and have been one of the dullest markets in the house. This is somewhat surprising, taking into consideration the splendid series of traffics published this week, and the imminence of the half-yearly dividend announcements. It is customary to lay blame for most of this world's ills upon the weather, but there can be no doubt that the present unseasonable conditions have not been without effect upon these shares.

Yesterday the market was ignored for the greater part of the day, but towards the close there was some hardening of prices. Today the tendency has been somewhat irregular, and business lisas been restricted.

The traffic returns are very gratifying. The North Western, for instance, report an increase of £16,000, which follows a gain last year of £21 000, the Midland add £11,700 to last year's increase of £21,000; the North Eastern have an increase of £13,000 on top of one of £12,100; and the Great Northern show & gain of £14,000, against an increase of £3,700 twelve months ago.

div.head: Americans.
div.p: The American section opened very firm on Monday, thanks to strong support from New York, and substantial advances were recorded. The upward movement was speedily checked, however, and for the greater part of the week the tendency has been much easier. The unsatisfactory reports regarding the prospects of the cotton crop, and uncertainty as to the monetary situation, largely account for this weakness.

More cheering advice came yesterday, and the tone improved correspondingly, but business was almost at a standstill in consequence of the Independence Day holiday in Wall Street. As a rule closing prices were about over parity. Great Northern Preferences were ap 2. Milwaukee 2, and Unions.
Today the tendency has again been favourable. Unions are in request at 144 5.

div.head: Egyptians.
div.p: After the recent excitement, the Egyptian market has this week taken matters more quietly, and business has been more limited in extent. The tone, however, has been very steady, and prices with a few insignificant exceptions, have been well maintained. • The best market is Delta Light Railway Preference, of which they were bought. ers yesterday about 9 and 9 They close today 9. National Bank has been down to 19, both were better again yesterday at 191 20 . Today they leave off at 20. Agricultural Bank are still being picked up by investors and close firm at over 8, while the

div.head: Mining.
div.p: Kaffirs were dull enough during the first two days of the week, the Paris settlement causing a good deal of nervousness. The tone is now much better, however, the rumours of failures in France having proved groundless. Yesterday the market was quite cheerful, and the leading Rand shares received a fair amount of support, East Rands improving to 8 and Modders to 4,15/16. To-day the tendency has again been favourable, though business has been quiet. Tanganyikas have been a good feature and have improved to 41-5.
